question.title: Why doesn't the Java compiler in IntelliJ IDEA complain about filename case mismatches?
question.body:
I'm learning Java and experimenting with compiling source files. I understand that Java is case-sensitive, and that the filename must match the public class name exactly — including the case.

public class HelloWorld {
   public static void main(String[] args) {
      System.out.println("Hello, world!");
   }
}

When I compile this manually in the terminal using:

javac HelloWorld.java

It works as expected. But if I try:

javac helloworld.java

It fails on a case-sensitive file system (like Linux), saying the file can't be found — which makes sense.

However, in IntelliJ IDEA, if I create the file HelloWorld.java and compile it like this:

javac Helloworld.java

the compiler doesn't seem to care about the case of the filename.
